title.value: Tackling hypo and hyper sensory processing heterogeneity in autism: From clinical stratification to genetic pathways
title.justification: The title is explicitly mentioned at the start of the paper and throughout the document.
title.quote: Tackling hypo and hyper sensory processing heterogeneity in autism: From clinical stratification to genetic pathways.

extractions.description: This paper investigates sensory processing heterogeneity (hypo and hyper sensory processing) in autism spectrum disorders. It explores clinical stratification and investigates genetic pathways associated with these sensory profiles using the dSSP score derived from the Short Sensory Profile (SSP). Data from 1136 participants, including autistic individuals, relatives, and controls, were analyzed, showing significant differences in dSSP scores related to genetic mutations in GABA-ergic pathways. The study provides insights into the biological underpinnings of sensory processing in autism.

type.justification: The study involves analyzing data from participants, conducting genetic analysis, and using statistical methods to investigate sensory processing in autism. This indicates an empirical research approach.
type.quote: Methods To characterize the hypo/hyper-sensory profile, the differential Short Sensory Profile (dSSP) was defined as a normalized and centralized hypo/hypersensitivity ratio from the Short Sensory Profile (SSP). Results: Including 1136 participants...

name.justification: The paper focuses on autism spectrum disorders, particularly investigating sensory processing heterogeneity and genetic pathways in autism.
name.quote: To explore the hypo/hyper-sensory profile among autistic individuals and its link with genetic alterations in GABA-ergic and glutamatergic pathways...

name.justification: The paper involves genetic analysis, focusing on mutations in GABA-ergic pathways among autistic individuals.
name.quote: Our genetic analysis tended to associate the dSSP and the hyposensitivity with mutations of the GABAergic pathway.

name.justification: The dSSP is a key methodological model developed in this study to assess sensory processing differences in autism, used extensively throughout the paper.
name.quote: the differential Short Sensory Profile (dSSP) was defined as a normalized and centralized hypo/hypersensitivity ratio from the Short Sensory Profile (SSP).

is_contributed.justification: The paper contributes the dSSP model specifically for the research of sensory processing in autism.
is_contributed.quote: We constructed a summarizing score as a normalized and centralized ratio of the hypo- to hyper- sensitivity derived from the SSP questionnaire.

is_executed.justification: The model is a scoring system applied to survey data, not requiring computational execution on GPUs or CPUs.
is_executed.quote: We quantified inter-observer stability using Kendall rank correlation (Supplementary Table 2).

is_compared.justification: The dSSP scores were used to compare sensory processing between autistic individuals, relatives, and controls.
is_compared.quote: Including 1136 participants... we observed a statistically significant dSSP mean difference between autistic individuals and controls...

referenced_paper_title.value: Development and validation of the short sensory profile
referenced_paper_title.justification: The Short Sensory Profile (SSP), which the dSSP is derived from, is referenced in the study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The Short Sensory Profile (SSP) was collected for autistic individuals at T0, month 3 and year 1 and 2 for all subjects of the autistic group.

name.justification: The SSP dataset is central to the study, providing initial sensory profiles that were used to derive the dSSP scores.
name.quote: the differential Short Sensory Profile (dSSP) was defined as a normalized and centralized hypo/hypersensitivity ratio from the Short Sensory Profile (SSP).

referenced_paper_title.value: Development and validation of the short sensory profile
referenced_paper_title.justification: The SSP is a well-established measure referenced for its role in assessing sensory profiles.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The Short Sensory Profile (SSP) was collected for autistic individuals at T0, month 3 and year 1 and 2 for all subjects of the autistic group.

name.justification: The datasets, PARIS and LEAP, provided participant data for the study's analyses and findings.
name.quote: Including 1136 participants (533 autistic individuals, 210 first-degree relatives, and 267 controls) from two independent study samples (PARIS and LEAP).

referenced_paper_title.value: The EU-AIMS Longitudinal European Autism Project (LEAP) : Clinical characterisation
referenced_paper_title.justification: Referencing the LEAP study affirms its significance as a large-scale project providing data.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The EU-AIMS Longitudinal European Autism Project (LEAP) sample study was composed of 384 autistic individuals and 280 individuals with typical development.
